title: Buy Levi Strauss Stock Because Innovation Creates a ‘Brand Halo’
text:
Text size

Levi Strauss & Co. stock was rising on Tuesday, helped by a bullish initiation from Macquarie, which thinks that the denim and apparel maker has plenty of runway for growth and room to be generous with shareholders.

The back story. Levi Strauss (ticker: LEVI) made its public debut in March, at $17 a share, and while it did jump to nearly $25 at one point, the stock has largely languished since. The shares dropped following its earnings report in July, and the company’s most-recent results, from earlier this month, also sent Levi stock lower.

What’s new. On Tuesday, Macquarie analyst WerlsonHwang initiated coverage of Levi’s with an Outperform rating and $23 price target, writing that he is upbeat about the company’s strategy and ability to stay relevant with consumers. “Levi’s has always prided itself by being at the forefront of innovation. This is important, as research has shown that companies with higher R&D spend will outperform in the long term,” he writes. “As such, innovation is one of the key tenets behind our Outperform thesis on Levi’s.”

Editor's Choice

He also highlights the company’s clean balance sheet—which could facilitate cash returns to shareholders in the future in the form of dividends or share repurchases—as well as a strong management roster.

Looking ahead. Hwang sees more catalysts to come for Levi’s especially as the company has “significant opportunity to diversify its revenue base by geography, by channel, and by gender” (as men’s clothing now accounts for nearly 70% of sales). He sees a core stable business and top-line acceleration for these underpenetrated markets driving results for the next few years.

He believes Levi’s has an opportunity to expand gross margins as well, thanks to better sourcing and more lucrative offerings, like laser-finished jeans, while high fixed costs related to its direct-to-consumer investments should start to taper off. In addition, he likes that Levi’s has embraced the resale market—which is expected to double in the next five years—via its partnership with Re/Done and the debut of the Authorized Vintage Program. “These initiatives may not directly impact the bottom line in a meaningful way, but they create a brand halo and bring other positive environmental, social, and governance related intangibles.”

Levi shares were up 3.9% to $17.69 late Tuesday morning. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 0.2%.
